question: Umblical cord contains:
prompt:
Umblical cord contains:A)3 arteries & 1 vein
B)1 artery& 3 veins
C)1 artery & 1 vein
D)2 arteries & 1 vein
output0: The umbilical cord contains three arteries and one vein, which provides oxygenated blood and nutrients to the developing fetus.
output1: The umbilical cord contains one artery and three veins. The artery carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, while the veins carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.
output2: The umbilical cord contains one artery and one vein. The artery carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, while the vein carries deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.
output3: The umbilical cord contains 2 arteries and 1 vein. The arteries carry oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus, while the vein carries deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

question: Which of the following temporal bone is the most common head injury arising fracture (temporal bone fracture)?
prompt:
Which of the following temporal bone is the most common head injury arising fracture (temporal bone fracture)?A)Vertical Fractures (longitudinal fracture)
B)Transverse fractures (transverse fracture)
C)Mixed fractures (mixed fracture)
D)Depressed fracture (depressive fracture)
output0: Vertical fractures, also known as longitudinal fractures, are the most common type of temporal bone fracture. These fractures occur when there is a direct blow to the temple, such as during a fall or a car accident. The temporal bone is particularly susceptible to this type of injury because it is a thin, flat bone that is located near the surface of the skull.
output1: Transverse fractures of the temporal bone are the most common type of head injury arising fracture. They occur when the bone is broken in a transverse direction, often as a result of a direct blow to the head.
output2: Mixed fractures, which involve both vertical and transverse fractures, are the most common type of temporal bone fracture arising from head injuries. This is because head injuries often involve multiple directions of force, leading to a combination of vertical and transverse fractures.
output3: The depressed fracture is the most common head injury arising fracture of the temporal bone. It occurs when the bone is crushed or depressed, often as a result of a direct blow to the head. This type of fracture can be caused by a fall, a car accident, or a sports injury.

question: A study to analyze the effect of antihypertensive drugs, using the case-control design (case-control study), the two case-control sample to be analyzed service hypotensive difference whether the blood pressure values ​​measured before and after the 3 months significantly different, researchers should use what is the most appropriate statistical methods?
options: B)Z single sample assay (One sample Z-test)
prompt:
A study to analyze the effect of antihypertensive drugs, using the case-control design (case-control study), the two case-control sample to be analyzed service hypotensive difference whether the blood pressure values ​​measured before and after the 3 months significantly different, researchers should use what is the most appropriate statistical methods?A)Paired t-test (Paired t-test)
B)Z single sample assay (One sample Z-test)
C)Pearson chi-square test (Pearson Chi-square test)
D)Independent samples t-test (Independent t-test)
output0: The most appropriate statistical method for this study would be a paired t-test, as the researchers are comparing the same individuals before and after the 3 months. This test will allow the researchers to determine if the blood pressure values measured before and after the 3 months significantly different.
output1: The Z-test is the most appropriate statistical method for comparing the means of two groups when the data are not paired. In this case, the researchers are comparing the blood pressure values measured before and after the 3-month treatment period. The Z-test is a one-sample test, which means it is used to compare the mean of a single group (the treatment group) to a known population mean (the mean of the control group).
output2: The Pearson chi-square test is the most appropriate statistical method for analyzing the difference in blood pressure values ​​measured before and after 3 months in a case-control study. This test is used to compare the distribution of categorical variables (such as the use of antihypertensive drugs) in two or more groups. In this case, the researchers are comparing the distribution of blood pressure values ​​in the case and control groups before and after the 3-month period.
output3: The Independent samples t-test is the most appropriate statistical method for this study because it allows researchers to compare the means of two independent samples (i.e., the case and control groups) and determine if there is a significant difference in blood pressure values before and after treatment. The Paired t-test would not be appropriate because it is used to compare the means of the same sample before and after treatment.

question:
Deepening the pulpal floor during cavity preparation
provides for
prompt:
Deepening the pulpal floor during cavity preparation
provides forA)Outline form
B)Retention form
C)convenience form
D)Resistance form
output0: Deepening the pulpal floor during cavity preparation provides an outline form, which allows for a better adaptation of the restoration to the tooth structure and helps to maintain the proper anatomy of the tooth.
output1: When the pulpal floor is deepened during cavity preparation, it helps to create a retention form that ensures the restoration will stay in place and provide a good seal. This is especially important for posterior teeth that have a tendency to flex and create a gap between the tooth and the restoration.
output2: Deepening the pulpal floor during cavity preparation provides a convenience form, which is a type of cavity preparation that allows for easier access to the pulp chamber.
output3: Deepening the pulpal floor during cavity preparation provides for resistance form, which allows for the best fit of the restoration and helps to prevent marginal ridge defects.

question: % of ectopic pregnancy seen in fallopian tube is?
prompt:
% of ectopic pregnancy seen in fallopian tube is?A)75%
B)90%
C)80%
D)67%
output0: Ectopic pregnancy is a condition in which the fertilized egg implants outside the uterus, typically in the fallopian tube. According to the American Pregnancy Association, approximately 75% of ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube.
output1: The correct answer is B)90% because 90% of ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube.
output2: According to the American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology, approximately 80% of ectopic pregnancies occur in the fallopian tube.
output3: The correct answer is D)67% because ectopic pregnancy is the most common type of ectopic pregnancy and accounts for approximately 67% of all cases.

question: Cephalic phase of gastric secretion ?
prompt:
Cephalic phase of gastric secretion ?A)20%
B)70%
C)10%
D)100%
output0: The cephalic phase of gastric secretion is the initial stage of gastric secretion that occurs before food intake. During this phase, the stomach secretes a small amount of gastric juice, approximately 20% of the total amount secreted during a meal.
output1: The cephalic phase of gastric secretion refers to the increase in gastric acid secretion that occurs before eating. This phase is important for the digestion of food, as it helps to break down proteins and prepare the stomach for the ingestion of nutrients. The cephalic phase is the most active during the early morning hours, and it peaks around 70% of the total gastric secretion.
output2: The cephalic phase of gastric secretion refers to the initial release of gastric juices into the stomach in response to the sight, smell, or thought of food. This phase is relatively short, lasting only about 10% of the entire digestive process. Therefore, the correct answer is C)10%.
output3: The cephalic phase of gastric secretion is the period of time during which gastric juices are secreted into the stomach in preparation for food ingestion. During this phase, the stomach is empty and the gastric juices are secreted to coat the stomach lining and prepare it for the incoming food. Since the stomach is always secreting gastric juices, the cephalic phase is 100% of the time.

question: Farrar gave :
prompt:
Farrar gave :A)Bone bending theory
B)Bioelectric theory
C)Piezoelectric theory
D)All of the above
output0: Farrar's theory of bone bending is a model of how the body responds to stress and strain. It suggests that the bones of the body are designed to bend and flex under stress, rather than breaking. This theory is based on the idea that the bones of the body are made up of a series of interconnected fibers, which can bend and twist under stress.
output1: Farrar gave the Bioelectric theory, which suggests that bones can generate electricity when subjected to mechanical stress. This theory is supported by the fact that bones contain specialized cells called piezoelectric cells, which produce electricity when deformed.
output2: Farrar's theory is based on the idea that the human body is made up of piezoelectric materials that generate electricity when subjected to mechanical stress. This theory suggests that the body is capable of generating its own electrical signals, which can be used to control muscle contractions and other physiological processes.
output3: Dr. Farrar proposed a bioelectric theory, which suggests that bones can detect and respond to changes in the electrical activity of the body. This theory is supported by the idea that bones have a piezoelectric property, which allows them to generate an electric charge in response to mechanical stress. Additionally, the theory suggests that bones can be influenced by changes in the body's bioelectric field, such as those that occur during emotional experiences.

question: No related acute cholecystitis (Acute acalculous cholecystitis) narrative, what's wrong?
correct_answer: Mortality rate lower than the acute gallstone cholecystitis
options: A)May occur in trauma, burns, patients with severe long-term injection of intravenous nutrition
B)Symptoms include right upper quadrant tenderness, fever, elevated white blood cell count
C)Mortality rate lower than the acute gallstone cholecystitis
prompt:
No related acute cholecystitis (Acute acalculous cholecystitis) narrative, what's wrong?A)May occur in trauma, burns, patients with severe long-term injection of intravenous nutrition
B)Symptoms include right upper quadrant tenderness, fever, elevated white blood cell count
C)Mortality rate lower than the acute gallstone cholecystitis
D)CT or ultrasound diagnosis
output0: The Turtle Technique is not related to acute cholecystitis, specifically acute acalculous cholecystitis. Acute acalculous cholecystitis is a rare condition that occurs when the gallbladder becomes inflamed without any gallstones present. It is more common in certain high-risk groups such as those with trauma, burns, or patients who have received severe long-term intravenous nutrition.
output1: Acute acalculous cholecystitis is a condition in which the gallbladder becomes inflamed without any gallstones present. This condition is more common in older children and adolescents, and the symptoms may include right upper quadrant tenderness, fever, and elevated white blood cell count.
output2: The mortality rate for acute cholecystitis without gallstones (acute acalculous cholecystitis) is lower than for acute gallstone cholecystitis. This is because the inflammation caused by acute acalculous cholecystitis is not as severe as that caused by gallstones, and the risk of complications such as perforation or gangrene is lower.
output3: Acute cholecystitis is a condition that can be difficult to diagnose, and the Turtle Technique is not specifically related to this condition. The correct answer is D)CT or ultrasound diagnosis.

question: According to the theory of J. A. Gray, sensitivity to rewards is based on:
prompt:
According to the theory of J. A. Gray, sensitivity to rewards is based on:A)The ascending reticular activation system.
B)The behavioral activation system.
C)The right prefrontal cortex.
D)The limbic activation system.
output0: According to J. A. Gray's theory, sensitivity to rewards is based on the ascending reticular activation system, which is a brain region that is responsible for regulating the release of neurotransmitters that mediate the reward response.
output1: According to J. A. Gray's theory, sensitivity to rewards is based on the behavioral activation system. This system is responsible for the development of behavioral responses that are associated with the experience of pleasure and reward.
output2: According to J. A. Gray's theory, sensitivity to rewards is based on the right prefrontal cortex. This area of the brain is responsible for the regulation of emotions and the processing of rewards.
output3: According to J. A. Gray's theory, sensitivity to rewards is based on the limbic activation system, which is responsible for the regulation of emotions and motivation. The limbic system is also involved in the processing of rewards and punishments, and it plays a key role in the development of social behavior.

question: Anterior Mediastinal nodes are included in which level of lymphnodes -
prompt:
Anterior Mediastinal nodes are included in which level of lymphnodes -A)I
B)III
C)V
D)VII
output0: Anterior Mediastinal nodes are included in Level I of the lymph node system. This level includes nodes located in the neck and thorax.
output1: Anterior Mediastinal nodes are included in Level III of the lymph node system. This level is responsible for filtering lymph fluid from the thoracic cavity and upper limbs.
output2: Anterior Mediastinal nodes are included in Level V of the lymph nodes. Level V includes nodes located in the neck, above the clavicle, and in the mediastinum.
output3: Anterior Mediastinal nodes are included in Level VII of the lymph nodes. This level is responsible for filtering lymph fluid from the thoracic cavity.
